content: Not a bad idea. I am no tree hugger, but I wonder how many tons of lead is discarded on this countries ground every year? If there is an alternate that works just as good and is less toxic than lead, why not? "http://www.cnn.com/2009/TECH/science/03/04/green.bullets/index.html"
reply: Not a bad idea. I am no tree hugger, but I wonder how many tons of lead is discarded on this countries ground every year? If there is an alternate that works just as good and is less toxic than lead, why not? "http://www.cnn.com/2009/TECH/science/03/04/green.bullets/index.html"
title: Should hunters switch to 'green' bullets?

content: The article seems to show that lead poisoning from bullets is a big problem. I have serious doubts about that. In some cases (like hunting waterfowl) lead projectiles can cause problems and are justifiably banned. But most hunters remove the meat of an animal that has been impacted by lead because that tissue is damaged; this reduces the likelyhood that someone will have issues with lead poisoning. I'm willing to bet that game killed by hunters is still safer than the beef and chicken you buy in grocery stores. At least wild game isn't fed newspaper, feces, and injected with steroids and hormones. Some shooting ranges are probably contaminated with lead. I have no problem with green ammunition being used there. Most indoor ranges are well ventilated and the lead is collected and recycled.
reply: The article seems to show that lead poisoning from bullets is a big problem. I have serious doubts about that. In some cases (like hunting waterfowl) lead projectiles can cause problems and are justifiably banned. But most hunters remove the meat of an animal that has been impacted by lead because that tissue is damaged; this reduces the likelyhood that someone will have issues with lead poisoning. I'm willing to bet that game killed by hunters is still safer than the beef and chicken you buy in grocery stores. At least wild game isn't fed newspaper, feces, and injected with steroids and hormones. Some shooting ranges are probably contaminated with lead. I have no problem with green ammunition being used there. Most indoor ranges are well ventilated and the lead is collected and recycled.
title: Should hunters switch to 'green' bullets?

content: quote: Originally posted by LineDoggie: Wasnt it already proven that Lead Shot poisoning was total BullSh_t IIRC? Steel shot also increased the number of Wounded Ducks and Geese because it's Density affected it's Kinetic transfer? No lead poisoning has occurred especially in waterfowl. title: Should hunters switch to 'green' bullets?

content: Interesting discussion. As someone who makes a living in and around chemistry, I've done a little digging into this subject. I also like to hunt and fish, and was curious HOW solid lead leached contaminants. The old-style soft lead "dumd-dumds", as well as some of the older sinkers (and your do-it-yourself, wheel-weight sinkers) were the big culprits when it came to lead leaching contamination. Most of todays harder lead alloys, used as core material for performance rounds, are inert due to the alloy mix. There is little to no threat of lead poisioning from those rounds. Infact, there is more concern, in medicine today, from the mercury content of the old-style fillings many of us have, than from hunting rounds, and bullet-weights (fishing)!!
reply: Interesting discussion. As someone who makes a living in and around chemistry, I've done a little digging into this subject. Most of todays harder lead alloys, used as core material for performance rounds, are inert due to the alloy mix. There is little to no threat of lead poisioning from those rounds. Infact, there is more concern, in medicine today, from the mercury content of the old-style fillings many of us have, than from hunting rounds, and bullet-weights (fishing)!!
title: Should hunters switch to 'green' bullets?

content: bi-sm-u-th shot seems the way to go over water. Lead shot and lead bullets , unless you are the one hit, are harmless as used. It is the subsequent oxidation and resultion oxides of lead that are poison. Make you "mad as a hatter" before you die. Look it up. But the average non commercial field hunting will never cause an accumulation of oxodizing lead enough to be dangerous. You can get almost anything you want by claiming something is "green" , matters not if it is or is not, the initial claim and attendent publicity is enough. I'm waiting for the "green" arsenic. "bi****h" gets nannied, how preopsterousis that?

title: Should hunters switch to 'green' bullets?

content: Remember when the Clinton administration proposed making our soldiers use green bullets? I do and I opposed it, mostly because they wanted to use tungsten bullets and intended to buy it from China, the world's largest tungsten producer. To me, it's not a good idea to buy your ammunition from a nation you may soon find yourself opposing, but that's just me. To the subject: There have been a lot of comments here questioning whether or not lead bullets are an enviornmental hazard. To those who question that, I'd suggest they visit any old military base, such as Ft's Polk or Benning or Bragg, and look downrange at any rifle range. The trees are dead for a good distance beyone the impact area and have been for years. There's virtually no vegetation. And they have water table problems related to lead concentrations. Is that merely a co-incidence?
reply: Remember when the Clinton administration proposed making our soldiers use green bullets? Is that merely a co-incidence?
